date.headline: The Afscheiding
date.text: This 1834 Conflict sowed seeds of disagreement that were brought to America.

date.headline: Rev. Thomas DeWitt Visits the Netherlands
date.text: Rev. Thomas DeWitt, pastor of an RCA congregation in New York, visits the Netherlands and meets the members of the Christian Seceded Church who had left the State Church. He begins a column in The Christian Intelligencer, the weekly periodical of the RCA to inform RCA members of this small group and encourage their support.<ahref&sup1

date.headline: Societies to Help Immigrants”
date.text: The  “Protestant Evangelical Holland Emigrant Society”was founded in Albany, New York by Rev. Isaac N. Wykoff to help any Dutch immigrants passing through Albany. Another similar society was started by Rev. DeWitt the next year specifically to help Van Raalte’s group as they immigrated west.

date.headline: Arrival in West Michigan
date.text: Van Raalte and about fifty immigrants arrive at the shore of present-day Lake Macatawa.

date.headline: First Peak of Dutch Immigration
date.text: For a variety of reasons, the 1840s saw an increase in Dutch migration to the United States. A myriad of political, religious, agricultural, and economic factors combined and resulted in an exodus of Dutch out of the Netherlands. Van Raalte and nearly all of those who left the RCA in the 1850s  numbered among these migrants. To learn more about events in the Netherlands at this time click here..

date.headline: Establishment of Holland Classis
date.text: Soon after arriving in West Michigan, the settlers organize their churches into a larger assembly known as Holland Classis. At its first meeting, Van Raalte brought up the need for Christian schools. However, the settlers barely had enough money for their own homes, let alone a private school. Instead, they proposed setting up a new public school district in Holland and established a school using public funds.

date.headline: Visit from Rev. Isaac N. Wykoff
date.text: Sent by the RCA Board of Domestic Missions to investigate the condition of the Holland colony, Rev. Wykoff reports that there were about seven faithful congregations. They are eager for assistance since their mother church in the Netherlands was providing little support, and Wykoff proposes to the Holland Classis that they join the RCA. According to him, their only concern is that they are not put under “ecclesiastical bondage.”&sup6

date.headline: Letter Sent to the RCA
date.text: In response to Rev. Wykoff, a group of colonists led by Van Raalte affirm their agreement with the traditional reformed confessions and express their desire to join the RCA. They even write that the flourishing churches in the East have a responsibility to support them.&sup7 This letter was signed in June by twenty-four elders and ministers from the Holland area. However, notably, no church leaders from Graafschap, South Holland, Drenthe, or Grand Rapids congregations signed this document.&sup8

date.headline: Financial Support from the RCA
date.text: The RCA Domestic Board of Missions begins sending funds to support the colonists

date.headline: Union of 1850
date.text: At their annual meeting, the general synod of the RCA votes to admit the Holland Classis into their denomination. A few months earlier, Rev. Van Raalte had visited Albany “to give and to ask for all necessary information which may facilitate the desired union”, and this meeting finalized the decision. For more on the long-term impact of this union on the RCA, click here

date.headline: Holland Classis Acknowledges Union
date.text: The minutes from this classis meeting note that the union with the RCA was “a source of joy and gratitude,” showing that the Holland churches officially recognized the union established in the RCA synod. However, no record exists of an official motion in the Holland Classis to join the RCA.

date.headline: Founding of the Pioneer School
date.text: With the help of funds from the RCA, Van Raalte organizes a secondary school known as the Pioneer School. Although all teachers were members of the RCA, instruction was given in the English language. This school would be reorganized into the Holland Academy a few years later.

date.headline: Beginnings of Conflict
date.text: Though the Union of 1850 was complete, not all was peaceful in the Western churches. In 1852,  Jacob R. Schepers is called by the South Holland congregation to be their minister. Schepers held disagreements with the RCA and had avoided their examination to be officially ordained. When Holland Classis refuses to recognize him as their minister, the South Holland congregation joins the Associate Reformed Church, another local church denomination.

date.headline: Rev. Roelof Smit Deposed
date.text: Rev. Roelof Smit is accused of slandering Van Raalte and stirs up controversy over observation of holiday services. He is also absent from a classis vote to found a Christian day school, the English Academy. He believed that this school was a step in the direction of Americanization and therefore away from pure doctrine. When Holland Classis deposes him for his “arbitrary and carnal conduct,” he leaves the denomination with 2/3 of the members of the Drenthe congregation.

date.headline: Protests Against Van Raalte
date.text: An elder in the Grand Rapids congregation, Gysbert Hann protests a tract, “Call to the Unconverted” that was promoted by Van Raalte. He said it promoted sentiments that taught that believers had to do good works to be saved. Abraham Krabshuis, an elder in Van Raalte’s congregation, also accuses Van Raalte of not preaching the Heidelberg Catechism.

date.headline: Gysbert Haan Withdraws from the RCA
date.text: Seeing no reason to remain linked to a church that was straying from the principles of the 1834 Secession, Haan withdraws from the RCA before he could be disciplined for dissension. Several leaders among the lay people in Grand Rapids, Holland, and Vriesland follow.

date.headline: Mass Secession from the RCA
date.text: Four congregations — Nordeloos, Polkton, Grand Rapids, and Graafschap — send letters of secession to the Holland Classis after voting to “return” to independence from the RCA. The congregations were concerned that the RCA had strayed towards more liberal theology and practices. Their specific complaints were the use of man-made hymns in worship, open communion, and not preaching the doctrines of total depravity and limited atonement. For more information on the reasons behind the secession, click here.

date.headline: Formation of the CRC
date.text: Ten delegates from the seceding congregations reaffirm their allegiance to the three forms of unity and officially form the denomination known today as the Christian Reformed Church (CRC). They send a letter to their mother church Netherlands, the CGKN. In this letter, they express a desire to rejoin this church on the grounds of their shared doctrinal convictions saying, “We share with you the same standpoint of being separated from all other protestant denominations” Despite repeated letters, the CGKN refused to take a side in the American conflict for several years.

date.headline: Civil War Starts
date.text: Though both the RCA and CRC supported the Northern cause, they varied in their involvement in the war. For more information, click here.

date.headline: Mergers Rejected by the CRC
date.text: Rev. Vandenbosch of the CRC proposes merging with the Old School Presbyterian Church and Rev. Schepers proposes that they join his denomination, the Associate Reformed Church. Both mergers are rejected by Classis due to differences in liturgy.

date.headline: Christian Education Promoted
date.text: Rev. Wilhelmus H. Van Leeuwen, the new pastor of First Grand Rapids CRC is appointed to teach future ministers in his parsonage. He also encourages Classis to found Christian elementary schools.

date.headline: Rev. Douwe VanderWerp Becomes Pastor at Graafschap
date.text: Referred to as “The Van Raalte of the CRC” Rev. VanderWerp helped solidify the CRC as a viable denomination. He trained seminary students in his parsonage, was the first editor of the weekly periodical of the CRC, De Wachter, and helped organize five new congregations across the Midwest. He also opened a “Dutch School” to teach children the Dutch language during the summer.

date.headline: Hope College Officially Chartered
date.text: Hope College is officially recognized as a University by the State of Michigan and graduates it’s first class of eight men. Led by president Phillip Phelps, a minister from the East and friend of Van Raalte, the school’s faculty, board, and students were all closely affiliated with the RCA.

date.headline: CRC Bans Masonic Lodge Membership
date.text: Masonic lodges in America served as mostly social and business organizations. However, many viewed membership as a sin because of the organizations secrecy, elitism, and roots in the European enlightenment. For more on this controversy, click here.

date.headline: RCA Drops the Word “Dutch” from their Name &sub26
RCA Synod Meets in Grand Rapids
Saugatuck and East Saugatuck Secede
date.text: Saugatuck and East Saugatuck congregations leave the RCA
